vaccines.name: Inactivated Influenza Vaccine IM
vaccines.administration: One IIV dose every year in the fall or winter2
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction2
- Moderate or severe acute illness with or without fever2

vaccines.name: Tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (Td/Tdap) IM
vaccines.indication: All people who lack written documentation of a primary series consisting of at least 3 doses of tetanus- and diphtheria-toxoid-containing vaccine<small><sup>2</small></sup>
vaccines.administration: Substitute 1-time dose of Tdap for Td booster; then boost with Td every 10 years<small><sup>1</small></sup>
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction2
- For Tdap only, history of encephalopathy not attributable to an identifiable cause, within 7 days following DTP/DTaP, or Tdap2

vaccines.name: Pneumococcal conjugate (PCV13) IM
vaccines.indication: Adults with immunocompromising conditions (e.g.Hodgkin disease, lymphoma, leukemia, sickle cell disease) are at higher risk for pneumococcal diseases & their prevention is very important because the infection can lead to death, hospitalization, and serious complications including brain damage, heart attack, hearing loss, or amputations<small><sup>3</small></sup> For all adults aged 19 through 64 years with immunocompromising conditions<small><sup>1</small></sup>
vaccines.administration:
- Have not received PCV13 or PPSV23: Administer PCV13 followed by PPSV23 at least 8 weeks after PCV13; administer a second dose of PPSV23 at least 5 years after the first dose of PPSV23 1
- Have not received PCV13 but have received 1 dose of PPSV23: Administer PCV13 at least 1 year after the PPSV23; administer a second dose of PPSV23 at least 8 weeks after PCV13 and at least 5 years after the first dose of PPSV23
- Have not received PCV13 but have received 2 doses of PPSV23: Administer PCV13 at least 1 year after the most recent dose of PPSV231
- Have received PCV13 but not PPSV23: Administer PPSV23 at least 8 weeks after PCV13; administer a second dose of PPSV23 at least 5 years after the first dose of PPSV231
- Have received PCV13 and 1 dose of PPSV23: Administer a second dose of PPSV23 at least 5 years after the first dose of PPSV231
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction to this vaccine, including (for PCV13) to any diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccine, or to any of its components2
- Moderate or severe acute illness2

vaccines.name: Hepatitis A (HepA) IM
vaccines.indication: For all adults patients with immunocompromising conditions who want to be protected from (HAV) infection if some other risk factor is present<small><sup>1</small></sup>
vaccines.contrain:
-Previous severe allergic reaction2
-Moderate or severe acute illness2

vaccines.name: Hepatitis B (HepB) IM
vaccines.indication: For all adult patients with immunocompromising conditions if some other risk factor is present<small><sup>1</small></sup>
vaccines.administration: Adult patients with immunocompromising conditions should receive 1 dose of 40 mcg/mL on a 3-dose schedule at 0, 1, and 6 months or 2 doses of 20 mcg/mL administered simultaneously on a 4-dose schedule at 0, 1, 2, and 6 months<small><sup>1</small></sup>
vaccines.contrain:
-Previous severe allergic reaction2
-Moderate or severe acute illness2

vaccines.name: Humanpapillomavirus (HPV) IM
vaccines.indication:
-For unvaccinated females through age 26yrs: Complete a 3-dose series of HPV2 or HPV42
-For unvaccinated males age 22 through 26yrs: Complete a 3-dose series of HPV42
vaccines.administration:
- 3 doses on a 0, 1â€“2, 6m schedule. Use either HPV2 or HPV4 for women, and only HPV4 for men2
- Must be at least 4wks between doses #1 and #2 and at least 12wks between doses #2 and #3 2

vaccines.name: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
vaccines.administration: 3-dose regimen 6 to 12 months after a successful transplant, regardless of vaccination history; at least 4 weeks should separate doses <small><sup>1</small></sup>

-Previous severe allergic reaction2
-Moderate or severe acute illness2
